response:
[start of motion plan]
The task is to give the pained man a thorough neck massage while grasping the neck.

Mapping World Motion to Wrist Motion:
The provided workspace image confirms the robot's end-effector is positioned near the person's neck area, grasping it gently with a gripper. The environment is a workshop table with stable surfaces around, and the person is leaning slightly forward. The neck is a flexible but sensitive soft tissue area, requiring careful force control and smooth motion. The robot's wrist is oriented such that the gripper is aligned mostly along the neck at a slight angle, grasping from one side. The scene clearly shows proximity to the neck and head, emphasizing careful controlled motions without sharp forces.

The labeled wrist axes correspond to the world such that:
- The red wrist X-axis is approximately aligned laterally relative to the neck, roughly "right-left" in the camera/world where positive X is motion toward the right side of the workspace image.
- The green wrist Y-axis is approximately aligned roughly upward-downward relative to the wrist, with positive Y going towards the camera-top side of the wrist frame (which corresponds to an upward and slight forward direction in the world).
- The blue wrist Z-axis is roughly aligned along the neck longitudinal direction, with positive Z motion approximately directed upward/forward along the neck as the neck is slightly inclined downward in the world.

The blue axis represents wrist Z-axis motion. It roughly corresponds to upward-forward motion along the neck in the world frame.
Positive wrist Z-axis motion will move the end-effector upward along the neck; negative motion will move downward along the neck.

Based off knowledge of the task and motion, in the wrist Z-axis, the object (neck) must move with small amplitude sliding motions primarily back and forth along the neck (± 0.01 to 0.03 m) to provide massage strokes along the muscle fibers.

The red axis represents wrist X-axis motion. It roughly corresponds to lateral side directions across the neck in the world.
Positive wrist X-axis motion moves the contact point laterally to the right side; negative moves left side.

Based off knowledge of the task and motion, in the wrist X-axis, the object must move with gentle lateral sliding and small lateral pressure shifts (± 0.005 m) to target neck muscles on both sides.

The green axis represents wrist Y-axis motion. It roughly corresponds to upward/downward relative to the wrist, roughly corresponding to world upward and slight forward.
Positive wrist Y-axis motion moves the end-effector upward; negative moves it downward (towards the table/head).

Based off knowledge of the task and motion, in the wrist Y-axis, the object must move with small amplitude vertical presses and lifts (± 0.01 m) to simulate kneading and muscle compression.

To accomplish the task in the wrist frame, the object must be moved with gentle sliding and pressing motions combining:
- Small forward/backward strokes along Z (± 0.02 m),
- Small lateral slides along X (±0.005 m),
- Small vertical lifts and presses along Y (± 0.01 m),
executed smoothly and repetitively to produce a thorough calming neck massage.

Wrist Force/Torque Motion Estimation:
Linear X-axis:  To complete the task, the robot must exert positive and negative force intermittently along the X-axis with magnitude about 5 N on the neck to provide lateral massage pressure while maintaining grip.
Linear Y-axis:  To complete the task, the robot must exert positive and negative force along the Y-axis with magnitude about 8 N to provide vertical compression and lift sensations supporting kneading motions.
Linear Z-axis:  To complete the task, the robot must exert linear positive and negative force along the Z-axis with magnitude about 6 N to perform lengthwise massage strokes along the neck muscle fibers.
Angular X-axis: To complete the task, the robot must exert small angular torque counterclockwise and clockwise about the X-axis up to 0.3 N-m to enable subtle wrist tilting and rocking aligned with massage motions.
Angular Y-axis: To complete the task, the robot must exert small angular torque clockwise and counterclockwise about the Y-axis up to 0.3 N-m to support rotational kneading motion around the neck axis.
Angular Z-axis: To complete the task, the robot must exert small angular torque clockwise and counterclockwise about the Z-axis up to 0.2 N-m to enable gentle twisting motions consistent with neck massage manipulation.
Grasping force:  The neck skin and muscles have moderate softness with friction coefficient around 0.5 - 0.7 due to clothing or skin contact. The mass of the neck segment under massage is low (around 3 kg). To maintain stable grasp without slipping but avoid injury, a moderate grasp force of 15 to 25 N is appropriate.

Python Code with Final Motion Plan:
```python
# succinct text description of the explicit estimated physical properties of the object, including mass, material, friction coefficients, etc.
property_description = "The neck is a soft tissue with moderate softness, mass approx 3 kg, friction coefficient about 0.6, requiring gentle grasp and dynamic forces for massage."

# succinct text description of the motion plan along the wrist axes
wrist_motion_description = "Gentle sliding and pressing motions with small amplitude along X (lateral ±0.005m), Y (vertical ±0.01m), Z (lengthwise ±0.02m) with smooth rhythmic changes."

# the vector (sign of direction * magnitude) of motion across the wrist axes [x, y ,z].
wrist_motion_vector = [0.005, 0.01, 0.02]  

# the vector (sign of direction * magnitude) of the forces and torques along the wrist's [x, y, z, rx, ry, rz] axes
wrist_wrench = [5, 8, 6, 0.3, 0.3, 0.2]  

# the grasping force, which must be positive
grasp_force = 20  

# the task duration, which must be positive (e.g. 5 minutes massage)
duration = 300  
```

[end of motion plan]

The task is to give the pained man a thorough neck massage while grasping the neck.

The robot is controlled using position and torque-based control, with access to contact feedback and 6D motion capabilities. 
Motions can include grasping, lifting, pushing, tapping, sliding, rotating, or any interaction with objects or surfaces.
Motion can resolve across multiple axes, so be careful to consider all axes of motion to accomplish the task.

Reason about the provided and implicit information in the images and task description to generate a structured plan for the robot's motion. Think about:
- Object geometry and contact points (from the image)
- Force/torque sensing at the wrist
- Prior knowledge of object material types and mass estimates
- Environmental knowledge (table, gravity, hinge resistance, etc.)

The robot workspace view labeled with the axes of motion relative to the wrist of the robot, placed at the point of grasping. The wrist of the robot may be oriented differently from the canonical world-axes, so this workspace view may help understand the wrist-relative motion to accomplish the task in the world.
World Motion Reference: As ground truth reference for world motion relative to the robot, the workspace camera view roughly corresponds to canonical motion in the world. 
Upward motion in the world corresponds to motion up workspace camera view image, 
Right-ward motion in the world corresponds to motion to the right of the workspace camera view image, 
And forward motion in the world corresponds to motion into the workspace camera view image.
The wrist frame axes will roughly correspond to these directions, but will be more aligned with the gripper-object relative motion.

Use physical reasoning to complete the following plan in a structured format. Carefully map the required motion in the world to the required motion, forces, and torques at the wrist.

Rules:
1. Replace all {DESCRIPTION: ...}, {PNUM}, {NUM}, and {CHOICE: ...} entries with specific values or statements. For example, {PNUM} should be replaced with a number like 0.5. This is very important for downstream parsing!!
2. Use best physical reasoning based on known robot/environmental capabilities. Remember that the robot may have to exert forces in additional axes compared to the motion direction axes in order to maintain contacts between the object, robot, and environment.
3. Always include motion for all axes of motion, even if it's "No motion required."
4. Keep the explanation concise but physically grounded. Prioritize interpretability and reproducibility.
5. Use common sense where exact properties are ambiguous, and explain assumptions.
6. Do not include any sections outside the start/end blocks or add non-specified bullet points.
7. Make sure to provide the final python code for each requested force in a code block. Remember to fully replace the placeholder text with the actual values!
8. Do not abbreviate the prompt when generating the response. Fully reproduce the template, but filled in with your reasoning.
9. Make sure to refer to the provided correspondence in the direction guide between motion in the world frame and positive/negative motion in the respective axes.
